head.title: Neither Slippery Nor Cold, but Just Like Ice

hedline.hl1: Neither Slippery Nor Cold, but Just Like Ice

abstract.p: Joel Berman has developed way to melt and reshape tempered glass, material once considered nonrecyclable; cast glass can be cut or sandblasted for structural uses; photos (S)

block.p: Joel Berman's cast glass is like a frozen lake -- thick, textured slabs that you can walk on. Now that he has rights to a transparent glass paint, there are 2,000 colors to choose from.

Mr. Berman, known for his large art-glass installations, invented a way to melt and reshape tempered glass, a material once considered nonrecyclable. The glass can then be cut or sandblasted for structural uses, like curtain walls or staircase balustrades and stair treads (left). Textured glass floors and stairs are, unlike ice, neither slippery nor invisible.

Mr. Berman recycles tempered glass debris that is produced when office buildings are remodeled. ''Our biggest problem is finding enough glass,'' he said. Prices for commercial projects range from $40 to $50 a square foot. Information: Joel Berman Glass Studios, Vancouver, British Columbia; (888) 505-4527.
